Any one can explain simple cell of electrolysis chapter? Thanks.
2 electrodes made from different metals in solutions containing the respective metal cations  and wires from electrodes with voltmeter in between
More reactive metal electrode oxidises and hence is the anode. The other is the cathode. Electrons flow from anode to cathode. Voltmeter registers a reading.
I dont understand why hydrogen ions accept electrons to form hydrogen
I thought copper is less reactive than hydrogen
Copper won‚Äôt oxidise because zinc  being more reactive than copper  oxidises instead
Hence copper electrode is the cathode
Metals can‚Äôt be reduced. So copper remains intact
U might wanna look at the d orbital

This one just swallow it for now. I ask my teacher the same qn when I was sec 3

There‚Äôs no copper ions in the electrolyte
It's actually magical cos it can be used as a noun  a verb  a pronoun  an adjective ...
H is negative in this case
? I said metals can‚Äôt be reduced
H is negative if it‚Äôs metal hydride
They should ask the teacher can hydrogen be both cation and anion
Just look at relative ease of discharge table
And ask yourself what ions are present at the electrodes
And look at whether it's electrolytic cell or...

In the example you stated  hydrogen ions and zinc ions are present at the cathode  hydrogen ions will be reduced since on the relative ease of discharge series H+ is lower than Zn2+  so H+ is preferentially reduced.
As simple as that  no need to complicate things further.
So if you were confused by 2 ppl above  hopefully this sums it up succintly
